qas.question: Name one of the reasons urbanization grew in China.
What did Nanjing and Beijing contribute to?
Under what rule was China not isolated?
During The Early MIng Dynasty Chinese merchants explored all of what?
What caused urbanization to increase in China?

context: In China, urbanization increased as <a5_0>the <a0_0>population grew<a5_0/><a0_0/> and as the division of labor grew more complex. <a2_0>Large urban centers<a2_0/>, such as Nanjing and Beijing, also contributed to the <a1_0>growth of private industry<a1_0/>. In particular, small-scale industries grew up, often specializing in paper, silk, cotton, and porcelain goods. For the most part, however, relatively small urban centers with markets proliferated around the country. Town markets mainly traded food, with some necessary manufactures such as pins or oil. Despite the xenophobia and intellectual introspection characteristic of the increasingly popular new school of neo-Confucianism, China under <a3_0>the early Ming dynasty<a3_0/> was not isolated. Foreign trade and other contacts with the outside world, particularly Japan, increased considerably. Chinese merchants explored <a6_0>all of the <a4_0>Indian Ocean<a6_0/><a4_0/>, reaching East Africa with the treasure voyages of Zheng He.
